p: TI [ 5, 7] is a perennial, densely hispid-pubescent herb, with scattered, stinging hairs throughout ( Figure 1). The stem is elongate, slender, and twining. Leaves are simple, alternate, serrate, stipulate, 2.5–12.5 cm long, 2–4.5 cm broad, densely hispid-pubescent. Regular, unisexual, and apetalous flowers are borne in terminal axillary. The flowering period is February, March, and June. Fruit is a capsule of 8 mm diameter, 3-lobed, more or less hispid. Seeds are subglobose, grayish brown, and smooth, with slight mottling. TI is geographically distributed in India, Sri Lanka, Burma, and China. In Sri Lanka, it is common in Jaffna, Anuradhapura, Minneriya, Galle, and Matara, as a weed of cultivation and waste grounds.
